name: Mina Patel
description: Mina is a 34-year-old UX researcher in Austin who treats recipe collecting like a living archive. She clips from everywhere—NYT Cooking, Bon Appétit, Serious Eats, food blogs, Instagram Reels, and family texts—then normalizes each recipe into a personal system. Using Paprika and a Notion database, she tags by cuisine, season, effort, cook time, dietary notes, and “weeknight/guest-worthy/freezer-friendly.” A lightweight script pulls schema.org Recipe data when possible; otherwise she OCRs screenshots and adds gram conversions, substitution notes, and realistic timing for her gas range, air fryer, and convection oven. Sundays are for “harvest and plan”: Mina prunes duplicates, chooses five dishes around what’s already in her fridge, auto-builds a grocery list, and aims for <5% weekly food waste. She’s methodical but playful—curating monthly themes (e.g., Oaxacan moles, Levantine salads), hosting swaps with friends, and writing a small newsletter of annotated links (“Saved & Served”). She respects creators by revisiting original pages, leaves structured feedback on results, and tracks a “no repeats within 30 days” challenge. Long-term, she’s compiling a versioned family cookbook that blends heritage recipes with her modern, measure-first workflow.
example_behaviours: Runs a Friday night “clip-and-sip” session to save and tag 15–20 new recipes from varied sources.
Uses an iOS Shortcut to parse a recipe URL and auto-fill tags in Paprika and Notion.
Converts cups/teaspoons to grams and records actual cook time vs. stated time (+/– minutes).
Maintains a substitution matrix (gluten-free, dairy-free, low-sodium) and links it to each recipe.
Batch cooks beans and stocks on Sundays, labeling portions for future recipes.
Hosts a monthly recipe-swap brunch where everyone brings a link and a bite-sized sample.
Leaves structured comments on blogs with oven adjustments and ingredient clarifications.
Runs “pantry purge week” quarterly to cook only from existing inventory.
OCRs her grandmother’s handwritten cards, adding photos and “heritage” tags.
Tracks spice freshness and schedules small-quantity refills to reduce waste.
Keeps a “to-try → cooked → keeper” pipeline with a quick 5-star rating and tasting notes.
Builds playlists by cuisine to match cooking sessions (e.g., Ethiopian jazz for wats).
Logs air-fryer and stovetop temperature deltas to refine future attempts.
Creates seasonal boards (spring asparagus, summer stone fruit) to drive weekly planning.
Publishes a monthly newsletter roundup with annotated links and substitution tips.
